author: TheDruggedGamer

text: I believe "The Last Gunfight" that you pointed out was the one that really shocked me in its lack of originality. I mean it's absolutely okay to use this kind of inspiration but there are better ways. For example Rude Kostry, who composed the soundtrack for Vietcong 2, did a great job with that one. Every song in VC2 is named after a certain 60's or 70's rock band and the pieces imitate the style of those bands very well but still they don't sound like copys of certain popular songs.
author: fotakatos

text: The soundtrack is good for a video game but in my eyes the composer kinda failed. He wasn't just inspired by Morricone's music, some of the tracks sound almost like shameless ripoffs of certain pieces by Morricone. I won't dare composing music that is so similar to my source of inspiration and then put my name on it.
author: fotakatos

text: Really? I didn't know...I could've sworn Yasunori Mitsuda did the CT soundtrack...but thanks for the info!
author: Arc13

text: Yeah... right... Clint Eastwood... and it wasn't Ennio Morricone who composed the music for Sergio Leone's movies, it was also Clint Eastwood! And it wasn't John Williams who composed the Star Wars soundtracks, it was fucking Clint Eastwood! And who the fuck is Hans Zimmer? It was fucking Clint Eastwood who composed the soundtracks for Gladiator and Pirates of the Caribbean! As a matter of fact Clint Eastwood is the mastermind behind all soundtracks ever written! You are a genius.

author: bushwhacker2k

text:
This is absolutely astounding. The part with the vocals reminds me of the scene in Once Upon a Time in the West where Jill mourns the death of her new family. The electric guitar at 3:14 vividly illustrates a confrontation between the three leads of TGBU, though different from the one at the end of the movie. Everything else is just beautiful, especially when the horn comes in. God.

This is why I am subscribed to you Supra. Keep it up.
